title: About the Open Standards Panel

details.body:
The Open Standards Panel works in the proposal stage in ‘how open standards are selected’. The Panel provides advice to Challenge Owners leading the work to adopt open standards. It also evaluates proposals to make evidence-based recommendations to the Open Standards Board.

The panel evaluates proposals and quality assures the work of Challenge Owners by:

  • making sure stakeholders have been engaged and informed throughout the development of proposal(s) relating to a specific challenge
  • verifying proposals put forward by challenge owners have been adequately researched and that there is sufficient evidence for the panel to agree on a recommendation

After assuring the work of Challenge Owners, the panel makes recommendations to the Open Standards Board, advising on whether a proposed standard is achievable and the potential impact its adoption may have on current systems.

Decisions on open standards will be made by the Panel Chair and will be based on a consensus of the Panel. The Chair is invited to attend the Open Standards Board to represent the Panel’s recommendations.

About the Panel Chair

The Panel Chair is a civil servant or public servant nominated by the Open Standards team and approved by the Chair of the Open Standards Board. Their appointment is for two years, but this term can be extended with approval from the Open Standards Board Chair. The Panel Chair may appoint a deputy if required.

The Panel Chair assembles the rest of the Panel members from the volunteers from government bodies and other organisations. All members are selected for their skills and expertise in their area and the current challenges being evaluated. The Chair will present the Panel membership to the Open Standards Board for review.

About the Panel members

The Open Standards team look for panel members with a balance of technical skills and expertise from a range of sectors. These volunteers join the core Panel in an unpaid capacity.

Volunteers are needed with a range of experience covering skills such as:

  • open standards-based implementations
  • specialist domain knowledge
  • interoperability solutions built on open standards.

Panel members must:

  • operate in the interests of the government as a whole and the users of government services.
  • not work to further the interests of a particular organisation or group of organisations.
  • declare any interests at the start of any Panel, working group or workshop they attend. All declared interests are published as part of the meeting note.
